newsitem.title: FRANCE: Cr. Lyonnais foreign business cut 25-30 pct - paper.
newsitem.headline: Cr. Lyonnais foreign business cut 25-30 pct - paper.

text.p: Credit Lyonnais chairman Jean Peyrelevade said the bank had reduced its international employees and branches by between 25 and 30 percent, financial daily La Tribune Desfosses reported on Monday.

Responding to criticism from EU Competition Commissioner Karel Van Miert that Lyonnais was not respecting the conditions imposed on the bank as part of a state restructuring, Peyrelevade said the bank was losing no time complying.

"Compared to the Commission's decision to force us to cut our international presence by 35 percent by the end of 1998, we are today, in terms of employees and branches outside of France, between minus 25 and minus 30," he said.
Credit Lyonnais has received two state bailouts and will need another before the bank is in shape for privatisation.

Peyrelevade said he believed he should have been consulted about the bailouts and added he hoped to be allowed to present his plan to prepare Credit Lyonnais for privatisation in person to authorities in Brussels.
He said the plan would be ready by the end of this year.

He did not say when he thought the bank would be privatised but said it needed to make progress on three fronts first -- improving its profitability, its credit rating, and restructuring and refocussing the bank's operations.
